questions.text: Which of the following drugs is excluded from the NDPS Act?
questions.solution:
• The NDPS Act (Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances Act) was enacted in 1985 to curb drug abuse and illegal drug trafficking.
  • Narcotic drugs are substances like cannabis, opium, and derivatives like heroin, hashish, and others listed under the NDPS Act.
  • Psychotropic substances include synthetic or natural substances that act on the central nervous system, such as amphetamine, barbiturates, and benzodiazepines.
  • Alcohol is regulated separately under state excise laws or the Excise Act, and does not fall under the purview of the NDPS Act.
  • The NDPS Act covers not just possession but also manufacturing, sale, purchase, transport, and consumption of narcotic drugs and psychotropic substances.
  • The penalties under the NDPS Act are strict, with punishments ranging from fines to imprisonment, depending on the quantity and type of drug.

Why Not Others:

  • b. Amphetamine:
    • A psychotropic substance known for its stimulant effects, used medically but also abused as a drug, covered under the NDPS Act.
  • c. Hashish:
    • A resin derived from cannabis, classified as a narcotic drug under the NDPS Act.
  • d. Heroin:
    • A highly addictive opioid, derived from morphine (opium), included in the narcotic drugs category of the NDPS Act.

Key Takeaways:

  • Alcohol is not regulated by the NDPS Act, but by separate excise laws. Narcotic drugs and psychotropic substances like amphetamines, heroin, and hashish are strictly controlled under the NDPS Act, with severe penalties for violations.

THE NARCOTIC DRUGS AND PSYCHOTROPIC SUBSTANCES, ACT, 1985 | India Code

questions.text: Mellanby effect is seen in ...
questions.solution:
• The Mellanby effect refers to the phenomenon where the physiologic and behavioural effects of alcohol are more pronounced when blood alcohol concentration (BAC) is rising compared to the same BAC when the level is falling or at peak.
  • This effect is thought to result from the development of acute tolerance to alcohol during intoxication.
  • Mechanism:
    As alcohol is absorbed and distributed in the body, the central nervous system (CNS) becomes more sensitive to its effects. Once the peak concentration is reached, the body adapts, leading to reduced sensitivity at the same BAC level during the falling phase.
  • Clinical significance:
    The Mellanby effect explains why individuals feel more intoxicated early in drinking sessions and less so later, even at the same or higher BAC levels.

Why Not Others:

  • a. Organophosphorus poisoning:
    • Organophosphorus compounds inhibit acetylcholinesterase, causing cholinergic symptoms (e.g., salivation, sweating, muscle twitching), unrelated to the Mellanby effect.
  • c. Opium poisoning:
    • Opium poisoning results in CNS depression, respiratory depression, and pin-point pupils but is unrelated to alcohol-induced acute tolerance.
  • d. Ethylene glycol poisoning:
    • Ethylene glycol causes metabolic acidosis and renal toxicity, primarily due to its metabolites like glycolic acid and oxalic acid, with no relevance to the Mellanby effect.

Key Takeaways:

  • The Mellanby effect explains the acute tolerance to alcohol experienced during rising BAC levels in ethyl alcohol poisoning.
  • Other poisoning types, like organophosphorus, opium, and ethylene glycol, involve different mechanisms and are unrelated to this effect.

questions.text: Which of the following does not cause metabolic acidosis?
questions.solution:
• Ethanol, methanol, and salicylate poisoning all result in metabolic acidosis.
    • Ethanol: Causes lactic acidosis due to increased NADH/NAD+ ratio affecting glucose and fatty acid metabolism.
    • Methanol: Metabolized into formaldehyde and formic acid, causing severe metabolic acidosis.
    • Salicylate: Initially causes respiratory alkalosis but leads to metabolic acidosis due to uncoupling of oxidative phosphorylation and accumulation of organic acids.
  • Fomepizole:
    • It is a competitive inhibitor of alcohol dehydrogenase, blocking the formation of toxic metabolites from methanol and ethylene glycol, thus preventing metabolic acidosis.

Why not other options?

  • Ethanol: Causes lactic acidosis, especially in chronic alcohol use or acute intoxication.
  • Methanol: Causes metabolic acidosis through its metabolites (formic acid).
  • Salicylate: Causes mixed respiratory alkalosis and metabolic acidosis through direct stimulation of the respiratory centre and metabolic disruptions.

Key Takeaways:

  • Fomepizole is the correct answer as it prevents metabolic acidosis, unlike the other substances which are direct or indirect causes of metabolic acidosis.

questions.text: Mc Ewan's sign can be elicited when blood alcohol is level is .......mg%
questions.solution:
• Mc Ewan's sign: In case of alcohol intoxication, the pupils are dilated. But in case of coma, pupils are dilated. During this stage, upon stimulation (pinching, slapping), pupils dilate and return slowly to their constricted state. This sign appears when blood alcohol concentration (BAC) exceeds 250 mg%.
  • At high BAC levels (>250 mg%), severe symptoms such as profound CNS depression, loss of consciousness, respiratory depression, and risk of coma are common.
  • Stages of Alcohol Intoxication:
    • Mild intoxication (< 50 mg%): Euphoria, mild impairment in motor functions, no Mc Ewan's sign.
    • Moderate intoxication (50-150 mg%): Impaired judgment, coordination issues, slurred speech, no Mc Ewan's sign.
    • Severe intoxication (150-250 mg%): Confusion, drowsiness, loss of motor control, but Mc Ewan's sign occurs only after exceeding 250 mg%.
  • Critical toxicity: Above 300 mg%, there's a risk of alcohol poisoning, which can lead to coma or even death without intervention.

Why not others:

  • < 50 mg%: Mild euphoria, little to no CNS depression.
  • 50-150 mg%: Stage of excitation: Motor incoordination, slurred speech, but no Mc Ewan's sign.
  • 150-250 mg%: Stage of Incoordination: Significant intoxication but Mc Ewan's sign is seen after 250 mg%.
  • >250 mg%: Stage of Coma: Mc Evan's sign may be positive

Key takeaway: Mc Ewan's sign is an indicator of severe alcohol intoxication, typically seen when BAC exceeds 250 mg%. Beyond this level, there is a high risk of critical outcomes like coma and respiratory failure.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male was brought to emergency with acute onset of hallucinations, violent behaviour and amnesia. Past history is suggestive of alcohol abuse for 10 years. The patient did not have alcohol for 3 days. He had tremors and high blood pressure with impairment of judgement and insight. The most probable diagnosis is
questions.solution:
• Delirium Tremens:
    • Acute organic brain syndrome usually occurring 2-4 days after cessation of heavy alcohol intake in chronic alcoholics.
    • Symptoms include:
      • Clouding of consciousness
      • Disorientation
      • Coarse muscular tremors
      • Psychomotor agitation
      • Hallucinations (tactile or visual)
      • Violent behavior
      • High blood pressure
    • Presents with significant cognitive impairment and impaired judgment.
  • Wernicke's Encephalopathy:
    • Characterized by:
      • Disorientation
      • Confusion
      • Memory disturbances
      • Nystagmus
      • Apathy
      • Ataxia
    • Occurs due to thiamine deficiency, often seen in chronic alcoholics, but lacks the severe agitation and violent behavior typical of delirium tremens.
  • Korsakoff's Psychosis:
    • Presents with an organic amnestic syndrome, including:
      • Impairment of short-term memory
      • Inability to learn new information
      • Compensatory confabulation
    • Insight is often impaired, but the acute symptoms seen in this case align more closely with delirium tremens.
  • Delusion of Persecution:
    • A type of paranoid delusion where a person believes others are conspiring against them.
    • Not associated with acute withdrawal symptoms or physical signs like tremors and hallucinations.

Why not others:

  • a. Delusion of Persecution: Lacks the acute symptoms of withdrawal, hallucinations, and agitation seen in this patient.
  • c. Wernicke's Encephalopathy: Does not account for the severe agitation and violent behavior characteristic of delirium tremens.
  • d. Korsakoff's Psychosis: Involves chronic memory issues rather than acute onset symptoms associated with alcohol withdrawal.

Key Takeaway: The clinical presentation aligns with delirium tremens, characterized by acute onset of hallucinations, violent behavior, and autonomic instability following cessation of alcohol in a chronic user.

questions.text: A drunk person was brought to the emergency department for examination. There was the smell of alcohol in breath, congested conjunctiva and dilated pupils but other findings were normal. Choose the correct opinion which can be given in this case.
questions.solution:
• Consumed Alcohol, but is Not Under Its Influence:
    • The presence of alcohol smell in the breath indicates recent consumption.
    • Congested conjunctiva and dilated pupils may occur with alcohol use but are not definitive signs of intoxication.
    • Other normal findings suggest that the individual may not exhibit signs of acute intoxication, i.e., not under the influence of alcohol.
  • Consumed Alcohol and Under Its Influence (Intoxicated):
    • This opinion would require abnormal physical findings such as altered mental status, muscular incoordination, ataxia, or significant changes in behaviour in addition to alcohol smell, i.e., Consumed Alcohol and Under Its Influence (Intoxicated):
    • The absence of these findings suggests the person is not intoxicated.
  • Has Not Consumed Alcohol:
    • This statement is incorrect due to the clear smell of alcohol in the breath.
  • Has Consumed Alcohol-like Substance:
    • While possible, the presence of alcohol smell strongly suggests actual alcohol consumption rather than a non-specific substance.
  • Why Not Others:
    • a. Consumed alcohol and is under its influence (intoxicated): Lack of abnormal physical findings rules out significant intoxication.
    • c. Has not consumed alcohol: Incorrect due to the clear Odor of alcohol.
    • d. Has consumed alcohol-like substance: The specific smell of alcohol supports the conclusion of actual alcohol consumption.

Key Takeaway: The clinical presentation indicates alcohol consumption without significant intoxication, supported by normal physical findings despite the alcohol smell and associated signs.

questions.text: All are the features of Barbiturate poisoning EXCEPT
questions.solution:
• Barbiturate Poisoning Features:
    • Hypothermia: Commonly observed; body temperature can drop as low as 31°C due to decreased metabolic activity and impaired thermoregulation.
    • CNS Effects: Includes:
      • Drowsiness: Marked sedation and confusion.
      • Dysarthria: Slurred speech due to muscle coordination issues.
      • Clumsy Movements: Lack of motor control leading to unsteady gait.
      • Nystagmus: Involuntary eye movement indicating CNS involvement.
      • Disorientation: Altered awareness of time, place, or identity.
      • Stupor and Hallucinations: Severe CNS depression can lead to altered perceptions.
      • Coma: A severe state of unresponsiveness.
      • Loss of Reflexes: Including corneal and deep tendon reflexes; diminished response to painful stimuli.
    • Pupil Response:
      • Pupils are usually constricted; minimal response to light is observed, with potential dilation in terminal stages of poisoning.
    • Respiratory Effects:
      • Breathing may be rapid and shallow or slow and laboured, with irregular patterns; potential for Cheyne-Stokes respiration.
    • Cardiovascular Effects:
      • Hypotension, bradycardia, cyanosis, and a fall in cardiac output; skin may feel cold and clammy.
    • Muscular Tone:
      • Muscles are flaccid with a significant loss of muscle tone.
    • Renal Effects:
      • Urine may be scanty or suppressed, often dark in colour, and can contain sugar, albumin, and hematoporphyrin.
    • Skin Manifestations:
      • Barbiturate "barb blisters" can occur on friction areas, containing serous fluid that leaves a raw surface upon rupture.
    • Gastrointestinal Effects:
      • Absent bowel sounds can occur due to decreased motility; hypothermia can indicate complications like bronchopneumonia.
  • Why Not Others:
    • b. Hypotension: Commonly seen due to depressed cardiovascular function.
    • c. Coma: A frequent result of significant CNS depression from overdose.
    • d. Constricted pupil: Typical in barbiturate poisoning, consistent with opioid-like effects on the CNS.

Key Takeaway: Hyperthermia is not associated with barbiturate poisoning; hypothermia is a prevalent symptom, making option a the correct choice. Understanding these features aids in accurate diagnosis and management.

questions.text: Which of the following clinical features are seen when seeds from the fruits given in the image are ingested?
questions.solution:
• Muttering Delirium: This condition is characterized by incoherent speech and altered mental status, often resulting from the anticholinergic effects of Datura. Patients may exhibit confusion, agitation, and hallucinations, which can lead to dangerous behavior.
  • Datura's Pharmacology: The seeds contain tropane alkaloids like atropine and scopolamine, which block the action of acetylcholine at muscarinic receptors, leading to a variety of physiological effects, including dilated pupils and decreased secretions.
  • Anticholinergic Symptoms: Other symptoms of Datura poisoning include dry mouth, increased heart rate (tachycardia), urinary retention, flushed skin, and decreased bowel sounds, all typical of anticholinergic toxicity.
  • Psychological Effects: The psychological manifestations can include hallucinations, agitation, and sometimes, violent behaviour due to the profound CNS effects of the poison.

Why Not Other Options:

  • c. Pinpoint Pupils: This is indicative of opioid or cholinergic poisoning, where acetylcholine levels are elevated. In contrast, Datura ingestion leads to mydriasis (dilated pupils), due to its anticholinergic properties, as it inhibits the parasympathetic nervous system.
  • d. Excessive Salivation: This symptom is characteristic of cholinergic poisoning, where increased acetylcholine leads to salivation. Datura results in dry mouth (xerostomia) and decreased salivation, which is typical for anticholinergic agents.

Key Takeaways:

  • Datura Seeds: Contain tropane alkaloids that lead to anticholinergic toxicity.
  • Clinical Features: Include muttering delirium, pin rolling movements, hallucinations, tachycardia, and mydriasis.
  • Management: Primarily supportive care, with physostigmine as an antidote in severe cases to reverse anticholinergic effects.

questions.text: 'Crack lung' occurs in ...
questions.solution:
• Crack Lung: This condition arises due to hypersensitivity pneumonitis, which is an inflammatory reaction in the lungs caused by inhalation of toxic substances, and in case of crack lung, inhalation of cocaine smoke.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Symptoms include chest pain, cough, haemoptysis (coughing up blood), dyspnoea (difficulty breathing), bronchospasm, pruritus (itching), fever, and diffuse alveolar infiltrates on imaging.
    • There may also be pulmonary and systemic eosinophilia, which indicates an allergic or hypersensitivity response.
  • Onset: Symptoms can develop 1 to 48 hours after exposure to crack cocaine smoke.
  • Mechanism: The use of crack cocaine leads to direct lung injury and inflammatory responses, contributing to respiratory distress and pulmonary complications.

Why Not Other Options:

  • b. Chronic cannabis poisoning: While cannabis may cause some respiratory issues, it does not lead to the specific syndrome of crack lung, which is primarily associated with cocaine.
  • c. Chronic mercury poisoning: Mercury primarily affects the nervous system and kidneys, leading to neurological symptoms, not specific lung symptoms.
  • d. Chronic opium poisoning: Opioids can cause respiratory depression, but they do not typically result in hypersensitivity pneumonitis or the specific pulmonary symptoms seen in crack lung.

Key Takeaways:

  • Crack Lung: A serious lung condition resulting from smoking crack cocaine, characterized by hypersensitivity pneumonitis.
  • Symptoms: Include respiratory distress, eosinophilia, and diffuse alveolar infiltrates.
  • Management: Supportive care and avoidance of further exposure to crack cocaine; corticosteroids may be indicated for severe reactions.
  • Prevention: Awareness of the dangers of crack cocaine use and its potential for causing significant pulmonary complications.

questions.text: Choose the INCORRECT statement about the plant given in the image.
questions.solution:
• Cannabis sativa: The plant in the image, commonly known for its psychoactive properties.
  • Active Principle:
    • Tetrahydrocannabinol (THC) is the main psychoactive component responsible for the plant's effects.
  • Types of Cannabis Products:
    • Ganja: Derived from the flowering tops of the female cannabis plant, not from the dried leaves and shoots.
    • Bhang: Made from the dried leaves and shoots of the plant.
    • Charas (Hashish): A concentrated form made from the resinous exudates of the cannabis flowers, leaves, and stems.
  • Legal Status: Cannabis and its derivatives are classified as illegal substances under the Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances (NDPS) Act in India, which criminalizes their possession, trade, transport, and consumption.

Why Not Other Options:

  • a. It is a deliriant poison and most commonly abused in India: Correct; cannabis is known for its psychoactive effects and is widely abused.
  • b. Tetrahydrocannabinol (THC) is the active principle: Correct; THC is the primary compound responsible for the psychoactive effects of cannabis.
  • d. Its possession, trade, transport, and consumption is a criminal offense under the NDPS Act: Correct; cannabis is illegal in India under this legislation.

Key Takeaways:

  • Cannabis sativa is the plant in question, with various forms such as ganja, bhang, and charas.
  • Ganja is derived from the flowering tops, not dried leaves and shoots.
  • Cannabis is illegal under the NDPS Act, making its use and distribution a criminal offense in India..

questions.text: A 28-year-old male was brought to the emergency department in delirious condition. His pupils were dilated, skin was hot, mouth was dry and he was trying to pull imaginary threads from the tips of his fingers. His relative gave a history of him travelling with some strangers to home. His belongings were reported stolen. What is the provisional diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Clinical Features:
    • Delirium: The patient is in a confused state.
    • Pupils: Dilated pupils indicate anticholinergic effects, typical of Datura poisoning.
    • Skin: Hot and dry skin is a hallmark of anticholinergic toxicity.
    • Behaviour: Pulling imaginary threads from fingertips suggests visual and tactile hallucinations, common in Datura poisoning.
  • History: The patient's travel with strangers and theft of belongings suggest potential drugging, often associated with Datura in criminal contexts.
  • Datura Poisoning Symptoms:
    • Anticholinergic Signs: Dry mouth, urinary retention, and diminished bowel movements.
    • Other Symptoms: Drunken gait, diplopia (double vision), and amnesia regarding the events following ingestion.
  • Why Not Other Options:
    • a. Opium poisoning: Presents with slow pulse, pinpoint pupils, and moist skin, which contradicts the findings.
    • c. Food poisoning: Typically includes gastrointestinal symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, or diarrhoea, which are absent here.
    • d. Barbiturate poisoning: Causes subnormal temperature, deep coma, and shallow respiration, not consistent with this case's symptoms.

Key Takeaways:

  • Datura poisoning is characterized by anticholinergic effects leading to delirium, dilated pupils, and hot, dry skin.
  • The criminal context (e.g., theft) and specific behaviours (e.g., hallucinations) point towards Datura as the likely cause.
  • Awareness of the clinical signs differentiates it from other types of poisonings.

questions.text: Run-amok is caused due to consumption of which poison?
questions.solution:
• Run-amok: This term describes a severe psychiatric disturbance resulting from the use or abrupt cessation of cannabis.
  • Characteristics:
    • Homicidal Mania: Individuals may exhibit violent behaviours, with an impulse to kill, often targeting someone they have a real or perceived grievance against.
    • Psychological Phases: After cannabis intake, users typically experience a cycle of:
      • Depression: Initial feelings of sadness or lethargy.
      • Excitation: Followed by heightened agitation or confusion.
      • Violence: The culmination of these phases can lead to violent actions against others, with the potential for the perpetrator to harm themselves afterwards (suicide) or surrender to authorities.
  • Legal Implications: Individuals are often not held criminally responsible for their actions during a run-amok episode since it is viewed as a mental disorder rather than a product of intoxication-unless they deliberately used cannabis to prepare for committing a crime.

Why Not Other Options:

  • a. Cocaine: While it can cause aggressive behaviour, it does not typically result in a "run-amok" state.
  • c. Alcohol: Alcohol may lead to aggression, but the psychological profile differs from the unique features of cannabis-related run-amok.
  • d. LSD: This substance causes hallucinogenic effects but does not commonly lead to the violent outbursts associated with cannabis use.

Key Takeaways:

  • Run-amok is primarily associated with cannabis use, leading to severe psychiatric disturbances characterized by homicidal tendencies.
  • The cycle of depression, excitation, and violence highlights the psychological impact of cannabis.
  • Legal responsibility is often mitigated in these cases, recognizing the condition as a mental disorder rather than mere intoxication.

questions.text: Which of the following poisons have a rotten egg smell?
questions.solution:
• Hydrogen Sulphide (H2S): This gas is well-known for its rotten egg smell, making it easily recognizable.
  • Other Poisons:
    • Phosphorus: Has a garlic-like smell, which can also be associated with other substances like arsenic, thallium, selenium, parathion, and malathion.
    • Cyanide: Typically emits a fishy or musty smell.
    • Ethanol: Characterized by a fruity smell, often likened to that of fermented fruit.

Why Not Other Options:

  • a. Phosphorus: Misidentified with a different odor (garlic), which is distinct from hydrogen sulphide.
  • c. Cyanide: Its fishy or musty smell does not resemble rotten eggs.
  • d. Ethanol: Its fruity scent is unrelated to the smell of rotten eggs.

Key Takeaways:

  • Hydrogen sulphide is identified by its rotten egg smell, distinguishing it from other poisons.
  • Understanding the characteristic Odors of various poisons can aid in recognition and identification in cases of poisoning.

questions.text: Gastric lavage is contraindicated in the case of:
questions.solution:
• Gastric Lavage Contraindications:
    • Kerosene Poisoning: Gastric lavage is contraindicated because:
      • Risk of aspiration is significant due to the volatile nature of kerosene.
      • Can lead to chemical pneumonitis if aspirated.
  • Indications for Gastric Lavage:
    • Should only be performed under specific circumstances:
      • Patient presents within 1 hour of ingestion.
      • Large amounts (> 1 ml/kg) ingested.
      • If kerosene is mixed with pesticides, heavy metals, or other toxic substances.
  • Precaution:
    • Intubation is necessary before performing gastric lavage to mitigate aspiration risks.
  • Carbolic Acid: Despite being corrosive, gastric lavage can be performed as it causes hardening of the stomach lining.

Why Not Other Options:

  • Barbiturate Poisoning: Gastric lavage can be performed if within the appropriate time frame and if large amounts were ingested.
  • Carbolic Acid Poisoning: Although corrosive, lavage may be indicated to reduce the toxic load.
  • Paracetamol Poisoning: Gastric lavage may be considered if the patient presents early, as it helps remove the drug before it undergoes metabolism.

Key Takeaways:

  • Kerosene poisoning presents a high risk for aspiration, making gastric lavage contraindicated.
  • Understanding the specific indications and contraindications for gastric lavage is crucial in the management of poisonings.

questions.text: With which of the following poisons has an 'intermediate syndrome' been associated?
questions.solution:
• Organophosphate Poisoning:
    • Intermediate Syndrome (Type 2):
      • Occurs 24-96 hours post-exposure.
      • Symptoms include:
        • Motor cranial nerve palsies.
        • Weakness of neck flexors and proximal limb muscles.
        • Respiratory distress.
      • Does not respond to atropine or oximes, distinguishing it from other types.
  • Types of Paralysis in Organophosphate Poisoning:
    • Acute Paralysis (Type 1):
      • Develops within 24-48 hours.
      • Symptoms include muscle cramps, fasciculations, and upper motor neuron weakness.
      • Treatable with atropine.
    • Delayed Neurotoxicity (Type 3):
      • Occurs 1-3 weeks after exposure.
      • Symptoms include:
        • Symmetric weakness in legs.
        • Cramps, glove and stocking paraesthesia's, foot drop.
        • Ataxia and stepping gait.
      • Does not respond to oximes or atropine.

Why Not Other Options:

  • Aluminium Phosphide: Associated with acute respiratory failure and cardiovascular collapse but not with intermediate syndrome.
  • Cocaine: Primarily causes cardiovascular and central nervous system effects; no known intermediate syndrome.
  • Opium: Primarily depresses the central nervous system leading to respiratory depression, but not associated with intermediate syndrome.

Key Takeaways:

  • Organophosphates are uniquely associated with intermediate syndrome, characterized by specific neurological deficits appearing after initial acute poisoning.
  • Understanding the timeline and symptoms associated with different types of organophosphate poisoning is crucial for effective management.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT true for aluminium phosphide?
questions.solution:
• Aluminium Phosphide Characteristics:
    • Protoplasmic Poison:
      • Inhibits protein and enzyme synthesis.
    • Phosphine Formation:
      • When aluminium phosphide is ingested, it reacts with moisture to produce phosphine gas.
    • Corrosive Action:
      • Has corrosive effects on tissues, particularly in the gastrointestinal tract.
    • Mechanism of Toxicity:
      • Interrupts mitochondrial electron transport by inhibiting cytochrome c oxidase and oxidative phosphorylation, leading to ATP depletion and cell death.
      • Excess superoxide anions and free radicals cause lipid peroxidation and disrupt cell membrane fluidity.
    • Grain Preservative:
      • Widely used in agriculture, particularly in northern India, for preserving grains.

Why Not Other Options:

  • Accumulation of Acetylcholine:
    • This statement is NOT true for aluminium phosphide. Instead, it is characteristic of organophosphate poisoning, which inhibits acetylcholinesterase, leading to accumulation of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction.

Key Takeaways:

  • Aluminium phosphide is a protoplasmic poison that produces phosphine and has corrosive effects, but it does not cause acetylcholine accumulation.
  • Understanding the mechanism of toxicity is crucial for effective management and treatment of aluminium phosphide poisoning.

questions.text: Which of the following does competitively antagonizes glycine by blocking postsynaptic uptake by brainstem and spinal cord receptors?
questions.solution:
• Mechanism of Action:
    • Strychnine acts as a competitive antagonist of glycine, which is an inhibitory neurotransmitter.
    • It blocks postsynaptic uptake of glycine at brainstem and spinal cord receptors, reducing glycine's inhibitory effects.
  • Effect on Nervous System:
    • The inhibition normally provided by glycine is decreased, leading to increased nerve impulse activity.
    • Without the inhibitory influence of glycine, motor neurons become excessively activated, resulting in constant muscle contractions (also known as "release excitation").
  • Target Areas:
    • Strychnine primarily affects the anterior horn cells of the spinal cord, notably impacting Renshaw cells.
    • It does not interfere with GABA, another inhibitory neurotransmitter.

Why Not Other Options:

  • Barbiturates:
    • Enhance the action of GABA, leading to increased inhibition, not antagonism of glycine.
  • Alcohol:
    • Acts as a central nervous system depressant; its effects are not directly related to glycine antagonism.
  • Opium:
    • Primarily affects opioid receptors and has analgesic properties, not related to glycine inhibition.

Key Takeaways:

  • Strychnine's role as a competitive antagonist of glycine results in reduced inhibition in the nervous system, leading to increased muscle excitability and spastic paralysis.
  • Understanding its mechanism is critical for recognizing symptoms of strychnine poisoning, such as muscle spasms and convulsions.

questions.text: A 19-year-old male was brought to casualty after ingestion of some unknown compound in the fields. On examination, conjunctiva was congested, patient was in respiratory distress with haemoptysis. Urine output was scanty. The tongue picture is as depicted in the image below. What is the provisional diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Key Clinical Features:
    • Paraquat Tongue: Characterized by ulceration and corrosion of the mouth and tongue, which is a classic sign of paraquat poisoning.
    • Respiratory Distress: Symptoms such as cough, haemoptysis, and dyspnoea are present due to pulmonary oedema caused by paraquat's toxic effects on lung tissues.
    • Ocular and Skin Irritation: Congestion of conjunctiva indicates irritation of the cornea and conjunctiva, along with possible inflammation of the skin and nasal mucosa.
    • Renal Failure: Oliguria (scanty urine output) suggests acute kidney injury, which can occur due to systemic toxicity.
  • Mechanism of Toxicity:
    • Paraquat is a herbicide that causes oxidative stress, leading to cellular damage, particularly in the lungs and kidneys.
    • Its ingestion results in free radical generation, damaging the epithelial cells of the lungs and leading to pulmonary oedema.
  • Why Not Other Options:
    • Organophosphorus: Causes cholinergic symptoms (e.g., salivation, lacrimation, urination, diarrhoea, gastrointestinal distress, muscle twitching) but does not typically cause paraquat tongue or significant pulmonary oedema.
    • Aluminium Phosphide: Causes gastrointestinal irritation and may lead to metabolic acidosis and cardiac issues, but the characteristic tongue lesions and respiratory distress are not typical.
    • Nicotine: Causes symptoms of poisoning, such as nausea, vomiting, increased heart rate, and respiratory distress, but does not typically result in ulceration of the tongue or significant pulmonary oedema.
  • Key Takeaways:
    • Paraquat poisoning is associated with ulceration of the mouth and tongue, severe respiratory distress, and renal failure.
    • Rapid identification and supportive treatment are crucial due to the high toxicity and poor prognosis associated with paraquat ingestion.

questions.text: Which of the following compound poisoning does not mandatorily require Pralidoxime as antidote?
questions.solution:
• Mechanism of Action:
    • Propoxur is a carbamate that causes reversible inhibition of acetylcholinesterase. This means its effects are temporary, and the enzyme can regenerate without the need for specific reactivators.
    • Carbamates like propoxur typically spontaneously hydrolyse and detach from the enzyme within 24 to 48 hours.
  • Treatment Protocol:
    • In carbamate poisoning, atropine is used to counteract the cholinergic symptoms (e.g., salivation, lacrimation, urination, defecation, gastrointestinal distress) but pralidoxime is not required.
    • In contrast, organophosphates (like malathion, parathion, and finit) cause irreversible inhibition of acetylcholinesterase, leading to the need for pralidoxime to reactivate the enzyme and prevent prolonged toxic effects.

Why Not Other Options:

  • Malathion: An organophosphate that requires pralidoxime for reactivation of acetylcholinesterase.
  • Parathion: Another organophosphate that necessitates pralidoxime for treatment.
  • Finit: Similar to malathion and parathion, it is an organophosphate requiring pralidoxime.

Key Takeaways:

  • Propoxur does not require pralidoxime as it causes reversible inhibition of acetylcholinesterase.
  • Treatment for carbamate poisoning focuses on atropine, while organophosphate poisoning mandates the use of pralidoxime to prevent irreversible effects.

questions.text: What is the specific antidote for treatment of paracetamol poisoning?
questions.solution:
• Mechanism of Action:
    • N-acetylcysteine (NAC) stimulates glutathione biosynthesis, which helps detoxify harmful metabolites of paracetamol.
    • It acts as a scavenger for free radicals, reducing oxidative stress on the liver.
  • Timing:
    • Administering NAC within 8 hours of ingestion provides nearly 100% hepatoprotection against liver damage caused by paracetamol overdose.
  • Other Antidotes:
    • DMPS (Dimercapto-propane sulfonate): A chelating agent used for heavy metal poisoning, not effective for paracetamol.
    • BAL (British Anti-Lewisite): Another chelating agent, primarily used for arsenic and mercury poisoning.
    • Atropine: Used as an antidote in organophosphate poisoning, not relevant for paracetamol.
  • Why Not Other Options:
    • DMPS: Not indicated for paracetamol poisoning; it's specific for heavy metal chelation.
    • Atropine: Specific for organophosphate toxicity; does not provide any benefit in paracetamol overdose.
    • BAL: Also a chelating agent, ineffective for treating paracetamol toxicity.
  • Key Takeaways:
    • N-acetylcysteine is the specific antidote for paracetamol poisoning, providing significant hepatoprotection if administered promptly.
    • Other options like DMPS, BAL, and atropine are irrelevant in this context and used for different types of poisonings.

questions.text: Which of the following is the characteristic feature of aconite poisoning?
questions.solution:
• Initial Symptoms:
    • Tingling and numbness occur upon handling the leaves or roots of aconite, which is characteristic of its toxicity.
    • Burning sensations may also be felt from the mouth to the stomach, leading to numbness in the mouth, tongue, and pharynx.
  • Further Effects:
    • This is followed by salivation, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhoea.
    • Later symptoms include dry mouth, thirst, and difficulty swallowing, with tingling extending throughout the body.
  • Neurological and Cardiovascular Manifestations:
    • Headache, giddiness, and pallor may occur, along with profuse sweating and subnormal temperature.
    • The patient may experience muscle weakness, ataxia, and slurred speech, along with potential twitching, cramps, and convulsions.
  • Cardiovascular Effects:
    • Initial tachycardia can progress to bradycardia due to AV block. Pupils may show hippus (alternating constriction and dilation), but later stages typically result in fixed dilated pupils.
    • Hypotension and cardiac arrhythmias may develop, with a risk of death from respiratory failure or cardiac arrest.
  • Why Not Other Options:
    • Hyperthermia: Not a characteristic feature of aconite poisoning; symptoms typically include subnormal temperature.
    • Hypertension: Generally not associated; hypotension is more common.
    • Increased salivation: While it can occur, it is a secondary symptom rather than a defining characteristic. Although there is initial salivation, later symptoms include dry mouth.
  • Key Takeaways:
    • Aconite poisoning is primarily marked by tingling and numbness, especially upon contact, along with gastrointestinal and neurological disturbances.
    • Understanding the progression of symptoms is crucial for recognizing aconite toxicity and implementing appropriate management.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs alter serotonin system and cause alteration in environmental awareness during which the individual maintains the capacity to recognise that what he is expecting is not real
questions.solution:
• LSD (lysergic acid diethylamide) is a powerful psychedelic drug that primarily alters the serotonin system, leading to profound changes in perception and environmental awareness.
    • Users often experience hallucinations, altered sensory perception, and distorted reality, yet they can maintain awareness that their perceptions are not real.
    • This state may include feelings of depersonalization, where the individual feels detached from their surroundings and self.
  • Other Options:
    • Methamphetamine: Increases the levels of dopamine and norepinephrine but does not primarily alter environmental awareness in the same way as LSD. It can lead to heightened alertness and euphoria but is less associated with altered perception of reality.
    • Cyclic Antidepressants: Primarily affect neurotransmitter levels but do not typically induce the profound alterations in perception or awareness characteristic of psychedelics.
    • Monoamine Oxidase Inhibitors (MAOIs): Work by inhibiting the breakdown of monoamines but do not cause alterations in environmental awareness.

Why Not Other Options:

  • Methamphetamine: Focuses on stimulant effects without significant perceptual changes.
  • Cyclic Antidepressants: Target depression through neurotransmitter modulation but lack psychedelic properties.
  • Monoamine Oxidase Inhibitors: Alter neurotransmitter metabolism without the hallucinogenic effects.

Key Takeaways:

  • LSD uniquely alters perception while allowing users to recognize the unreality of their experiences.
  • Understanding the different mechanisms and effects of these drugs is crucial for distinguishing their impacts on mental state and perception.

questions.text: Match the following according to appropriate antidote to the poison and choose the correct option.
questions.solution:
• Nicotine (1):
    • Antidote: Mecamylamine (E)
    • Mechanism: A competitive antagonist of nicotinic receptors, effective in managing severe nicotine toxicity by blocking its effects on the nervous system.
  • Hydrogen Cyanide (HCN) (2):
    • Antidote: Amyl Nitrite (C)
    • Mechanism: Induces methemoglobinemia, allowing cyanide to bind to methaemoglobin, thus detoxifying it. This is a critical emergency treatment for cyanide poisoning.
  • Paracetamol (3):
    • Antidote: N-Acetylcysteine (B)
    • Mechanism: Restores glutathione levels in the liver, effectively detoxifying harmful metabolites from paracetamol overdose. Administered within 8 hours for maximum efficacy.
  • Morphine (4):
    • Antidote: Naloxone (A)
    • Mechanism: An opioid receptor antagonist that quickly reverses the effects of opioid overdose, particularly respiratory depression, making it a crucial lifesaving intervention.

Key Takeaways:

  • Understanding antidote mechanisms is essential for effective poisoning management.
  • Mecamylamine, Amyl Nitrite, N-Acetylcysteine, and Naloxone are specific to their respective toxins, highlighting the importance of proper matching in clinical settings.

questions.text: Which of the following is/are a feature/s of drug habituation?

Choose the correct response about mechanism of action of carbon monoxide (CO)
i) Affinity to myoglobin is about 40 times greater than oxygen
ii) Causes direct myocardial depression
iii) Affinity to haemoglobin is 200-300 times greater than oxygen
iv) Produces death due to histotoxic anoxia
v) Acts as chemical asphyxiant
questions.solution:
• Affinity to Myoglobin: Carbon monoxide has an affinity for myoglobin 40 times greater than oxygen, causing direct myocardial depression, reducing the heart's ability to pump effectively.
  • Affinity to Haemoglobin: CO's affinity for haemoglobin is 200-300 times greater than oxygen, leading to the formation of carboxyhaemoglobin, which prevents oxygen transport.
  • Anaemic Anoxia: CO does not cause histotoxic anoxia but anaemic anoxia by displacing oxygen from haemoglobin, leading to tissue hypoxia.
  • Chemical Asphyxiant: CO is a chemical asphyxiant, meaning it prevents the normal use of oxygen by the body.

Why Not Others?

  • iv) Produces death due to histotoxic anoxia: This mechanism describes agents like cyanide, not carbon monoxide, which causes anaemic anoxia.

Key Takeaways:

  • CO binds to haemoglobin and myoglobin with high affinity, impairing oxygen transport and tissue oxygenation.
  • It acts as a chemical asphyxiant, causing anaemic anoxia and myocardial depression, ultimately leading to death in severe cases.

questions.text: Conium is a type of
questions.solution:
• Conium (Hemlock) is classified as a peripheral poison, like curare.
  • Active Compound: Contains coniine, found in unripe fruits, seeds, leaves, and roots.
  • Sensory Effects: It has a nauseating taste and a mousy odor.
  • Mechanism of Action: Causes progressive motor paralysis, moving from extremities upwards, eventually leading to coma and death due to respiratory paralysis.
  • Death Mechanism: Death occurs from respiratory paralysis as muscles involved in breathing are affected.

Why Not Others:

  • a) CNS Stimulant poison: Conium acts on the peripheral nervous system, not the central nervous system, causing paralysis rather than stimulation.
  • b) Irritant poison: Irritant poisons usually affect the gastrointestinal tract causing vomiting or diarrhoea. Conium's primary action is neurological, not irritant.
  • c) Spinal poison: Although it affects nerves, it does not primarily act on the spinal cord but on the peripheral motor neurons.

Key Takeaways:

  • Conium is a peripheral poison, affecting motor neurons, leading to paralysis and respiratory failure.
  • Not an irritant or CNS poison, it causes motor paralysis without significant CNS stimulation or GI irritation.

questions.text: Anthrax belongs to which category of biological warfare agent?
questions.solution:
• Category A agents are high-priority biological warfare agents, characterized by:
    • Ease of transmission and dissemination.
    • High mortality rates and potential for major public health impact.
    • Potential to cause public panic and requiring special public health preparedness.
  • Anthrax (Bacillus anthracis) is included in Category A, along with agents like Botulinum toxin, Smallpox, Bubonic plague, and Viral haemorrhagic fever.

Why Not Others:

  • b) Category B: Includes agents like Brucellosis, Salmonella, and Q-fever with lower mortality rates and moderate ease of dissemination, but Anthrax is more dangerous.
  • c) Category C: Emerging pathogens like Nipah virus or SARS belong here. They pose future threats due to potential mass dissemination, but Anthrax is already classified as Category A.
  • d) None of the above: This option is incorrect because Anthrax clearly fits within Category A.

Key Takeaways:

  • Anthrax is a Category A biological warfare agent, known for high mortality, ease of dissemination, and major public health threats.
